questions.neutral: Heard the streets are tense again?

hobby.message: That camera still your favorite weapon?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Streets, rumblings, I've heard whispers too.
Tensions flicker in shadows like a candle's flame, don't they?
I keep to my typewriters—quiet, methodical, enduring.
The city's darkness doesn't reach them, keep 'em aligned.
Restored one last night, focus keeps the rest away.
Yes, those streets aren't quiet anymore, are they?
Whispers and echoes of what's out there, best avoided.
I find solace in my typewriters, sturdy companions.
The past speaks more clearly when machines are silent.
Even the blackout couldn't dim my progress on an Underwood.
Yeah, Alex, the streets are buzzing, no denying that.
It's a reminder of what changes and what remains.
Spent last night with an Underwood No. 5—my typewriter hobby.
Even candlelight didn't stop me; soothing to restore history.
Feels like the old ways, something grounding amid chaos.
Certainly, Alex, the streets murmur loudly these days.
Funny how chaos makes one retreat to simpler joys.
I restore typewriters; spent the blackout with one, actually.
An old Underwood No. 5—a beautiful machine; pure mechanics, calming.
There, dust turns to stories, tensions fade into quiet focus.
Yes, Alex, unrest is like the city breathing unevenly.
Makes you treasure the quiet crafts, you know?
I've loved restoring typewriters since before the BCI reigned.
An Underwood No. 5 kept me busy through the blackout; all focus, no noise.
These machines, they're sincere—a calming honesty in their mechanics, like old friends.
hobby_answer: New piece arrived, but timing's not right now.
Restoring got trickier with recent power plays around.
You know the city's tense, too much flux for comfort.
Can't be too careful; even machines draw the eye.
Just keeping things simple, avoiding unnecessary attention.
Yeah, a new one, a bit dusty, a bit slow lately.
Blackouts make it more a hobby in the shadows, if you catch my drift.
Hard to focus when the city's buzzing like it is.
Difficult keeping my head down with all this noise.
Some old habits worth maintaining, even with the disruptions.
Got a new typewriter just before all these blackouts hit.
Power cuts make cleaning it up a challenge, though.
Feels like each key's a part of history, right?
The city's changing rhythm adds its own layer to the hobby.
Noisy times these days, hard to find quiet moments.
Picked up a Remington before the last big outage.
Tried fixing it by candlelight—reminded me of other darker days.
Funny how old machines can tell you a lot about our current climate.
All the unrest, it seeps in, even when I try to focus on typebars and ink.
Balance's off lately, in the city and in my own restoration efforts.
Ah, Alex, got myself a Remington 10, a beaut once.
Been tinkering by candlelight since that damned blackout.
Reminds me of my early days in the Council, when uncertainty was the norm.
This unrest… affects even the quiet things, like my routine with those machines.
Seems typewriters and I are like barometers, measuring the city's state these days.
